action.action-desc: Mr. Budd introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Oversight and Reform

form.official-title: To amend the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 to require Senior Executive Service and schedule C employees to disclose Federal student loan debt, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Federal Employee Student Debt Transparency Act.

section.header: Disclosure of Federal student loan debt by SES and schedule C employees
section.text: Section 102 of the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 (5 U.S.C. App. 101 et seq.) is amended by adding at the end the following:

paragraph.text: Not later than 60 days after the date of enactment of the Federal Employee Student Debt Transparency Act, and not later than February 28 of each year thereafter, a covered employee shall file a report containing a full and complete statement of the outstanding balance of principal and interest owed by such employee on—

subparagraph.text: each loan made under part D of title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1071 et seq.); and
any loan made, insured, or guaranteed under part B or E of such Act.

paragraph.text: Within 60 days of assuming the position of a covered employee, an individual shall file a report containing the information required under paragraph (1).
Not later than May 1 of each year, the Director of the Office of Government Ethics shall transmit to Congress a report containing—

subparagraph.text: the total amount owed by all covered employees as disclosed under paragraph (1); and
the name of any covered employee who failed to file or report any information required to be reported under such paragraph.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, the term covered employee means any employee of the executive branch who occupies—

subparagraph.text: a Senior Executive Service position (as that term is defined in section 3132(a) of title 5, United States Code); or
a position of a confidential or policy-determining character under schedule C of subpart C of part 213 of title 5, Code of Federal Regulations.
